citations.narrative:
Facility records document an incident involving prolonged, excessive ozone exposure for 11 King, 13 Gentoo and 10
Macaroni penguins inside their exhibit enclosure; the King penguins, in particular, were adversely affected (ID numbers
B19029, B19036, B19028, B19033, B24002, B19031, B19034, B19032, B19030, B19035 and B24003). Water Quality
Specialists in charge of monitoring the water life support systems performed daily reviews of Oxidation Reduction
Potential (ORP) readings and recorded them in a Daily Water Quality Log. They noticed that ORP readings were
consistently very high beginning 5/22/2025. Despite their awareness of this continuing trend leading up to the incident,
none of the employees started efforts to mitigate the issue until the birds exhibited symptoms days later. Employees
notified the veterinary staff when they observed the penguins’ abnormal symptoms, and took immediate measures to
eliminate the excess ozone from the air and water inside the exhibit. According to the attending veterinarian, several
penguins had higher than usual respiratory rates and some were coughing on 05/24/2025, but they improved throughout
the day without treatment; the following day, five penguins (four King penguins and one Gentoo penguin) were reported to
be lethargic, coughing and head shaking. The penguins were observed by a staff veterinarian who noted these symptoms
to be mild and not requiring treatment. On 05/26/2025, a King penguin named "Valentino" was reported to be lethargic,
but swam and ate well; this bird and all the others made a complete recovery. An internal investigation revealed that the
incident occurred due to a combination of equipment malfunction and failure by employees to take remedial steps when
high readings were first noticed, before the birds were affected. The facility devised new procedures and additional
training for staff and is in the process of replacing equipment as a permanent, mechanical corrective measure. All of the
penguins appeared to be in good health and behaving normally at the time of inspection.
Failure to act to correct known, detrimental conditions in a timely manner caused the penguins discomfort and illness, and
could have resulted in permanent injury or death. The licensee must ensure that all animals are exhibited only for periods
of time and under conditions consistent with their good health and well-being.
TO BE FULLY CORRECTED BY 08/15/2025

Eight adult chimpanzees have access to an indoor holding area where there is peeled paint and exposed, rusted metal
that is beginning to crack and flake on the surfaces of some doors and windows where the animals can easily grasp.
Rusty surfaces are porous and not easily cleaned and sanitized, and sharp points can develop that pose a risk of injury to
the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come into contact with non-human primates are free of
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization or results in the development of sharp points.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/15/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(d)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
Facility records document an incident involving prolonged, excessive ozone exposure for 11 King, 13 Gentoo and 10 
Macaroni penguins inside their exhibit enclosure; the King penguins, in particular, were adversely affected (ID numbers 
B19029, B19036, B19028, B19033, B24002, B19031, B19034, B19032, B19030, B19035 and B24003). Water Quality 
Specialists in charge of monitoring the water life support systems performed daily reviews of Oxidation Reduction 
Potential (ORP) readings and recorded them in a Daily Water Quality Log. They noticed that ORP readings were 
consistently very high beginning 5/22/2025. Despite their awareness of this continuing trend leading up to the incident, 
none of the employees started efforts to mitigate the issue until the birds exhibited symptoms days later. Employees 
notified the veterinary staff when they observed the penguins’ abnormal symptoms, and took immediate measures to 
eliminate the excess ozone from the air and water inside the exhibit. According to the attending veterinarian, several 
penguins had higher than usual respiratory rates and some were coughing on 05/24/2025, but they improved throughout 
the day without treatment; the following day, five penguins (four King penguins and one Gentoo penguin) were reported to 
be lethargic, coughing and head shaking. The penguins were observed by a staff veterinarian who noted these symptoms 
to be mild and not requiring treatment. On 05/26/2025, a King penguin named "Valentino" was reported to be lethargic, 
but swam and ate well; this bird and all the others made a complete recovery. An internal investigation revealed that the 
incident occurred due to a combination of equipment malfunction and failure by employees to take remedial steps when 
high readings were first noticed, before the birds were affected. The facility devised new procedures and additional 
training for staff and is in the process of replacing equipment as a permanent, mechanical corrective measure. All of the 
penguins appeared to be in good health and behaving normally at the time of inspection. 
Failure to act to correct known, detrimental conditions in a timely manner caused the penguins discomfort and illness, and 
could have resulted in permanent injury or death. The licensee must ensure that all animals are exhibited only for periods 
of time and under conditions consistent with their good health and well-being. 
TO BE FULLY CORRECTED BY 08/15/2025 
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Eight adult chimpanzees have access to an indoor holding area where there is peeled paint and exposed, rusted metal 
that is beginning to crack and flake on the surfaces of some doors and windows where the animals can easily grasp.  
Rusty surfaces are porous and not easily cleaned and sanitized, and sharp points can develop that pose a risk of injury to

the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come into contact with non-human primates are free of 
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization or results in the development of sharp points. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/15/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
